title: Common Requirements Document Baseline
statement: A common requirements document shall be established and maintained to provide a standardized starting point for software design. This document must be adaptable to allow for customization to meet specific country or system needs, while ensuring the core product fulfills needs across various scheme designs and structures.
acceptance_criteria: A version-controlled common requirements document is created and approved.
The document is used as the foundational input for software design and development activities.
A documented process exists for extending or customizing the common requirements for specific implementations (e.g., country-specific regulations).

metadata.raw_input: While software may have to be further customized to meet the specific needs of a country or system, a common requirements document provides a starting point for software design and can help software developers create a product that fulfills needs across scheme designs and structures.

title: Data Lifecycle and Flow Analysis
statement: A comprehensive analysis of business processes must be conducted and documented to identify and map the complete data lifecycle. This includes all points of data entry (e.g., direct collection, third-party system integration), all methods of data processing and analysis, and all channels of data sharing with internal users and external systems.
regulation: GDPR Art. 30 Records of processing activities
acceptance_criteria: A data flow diagram (DFD) for the system is created and maintained.
A data inventory document exists, detailing all data types, their sources, storage locations, and purposes.
The documentation clearly identifies all data entry points into the system.
The documentation details all major data processing and analysis steps.
The documentation identifies all internal and external data sharing points and mechanisms.

metadata.raw_input: An analysis of business processes can help determine where data are entering the system (either directly collected or coming from another system), how data are processed and analyzed, and how data are shared with users and other systems.

title: Global Requirements as a Baseline
statement: A country or organization will define specific requirements for its specific needs. The benefit of a set of globally defined common requirements is to provide an advanced starting point to review best practices and save time and resources in the development process.
acceptance_criteria: A documented review of applicable global standards (e.g., ISO, HIPAA, GDPR) is completed at the project's outset.
System requirements are demonstrably based on or mapped to these reviewed standards.
A formal process exists for defining and justifying country-specific or organization-specific requirements.

title: Evaluate Solution Alternatives
statement: A defined process must be used to evaluate multiple solution alternatives to ensure the selected system best matches the complex and diverse organizational needs, including all relevant compliance and security standards.
acceptance_criteria: A documented procedure for evaluating and selecting new systems is established and approved.
The evaluation procedure includes a scoring matrix or checklist that addresses functional requirements, security controls, regulatory compliance, usability, and total cost of ownership.
Evidence exists that the selection process was followed, including completed evaluation reports for the chosen system and its alternatives.
The final selection is formally justified and documented, demonstrating how the chosen system best meets organizational needs.

title: Comparative Software Package Evaluation
statement: A formal evaluation process must be established to compare multiple software packages. This process must acknowledge that no single package may be superior across all functional, security, and performance requirements, and it must provide a framework for making a risk-based selection based on a comprehensive analysis of strengths and weaknesses.
regulation: HIPAA Security Rule - 45 CFR §164.308(a)(1)(ii)(A) Risk Analysis
acceptance_criteria: A documented software evaluation matrix is created and approved.
The matrix includes weighted scores for key requirement categories (e.g., Security, Usability, Functionality, Compliance).
A risk assessment is performed and documented for the top candidate packages.
The final selection is documented with a justification report referencing the evaluation matrix and risk assessment.

metadata.raw_input: Not every software package will be equally strong across all requirements.

title: Business Process Visualization
statement: A graphical representation of a business process helps tell a story of who participates in a process, what types of information are exchanged between the participants, and how the work is accomplished.
acceptance_criteria: The system shall provide a graphical interface to display business process workflows.
The graphical representation must clearly label all actors/roles involved in the process.
The diagram must illustrate the flow and exchange of information between actors.
The sequence of steps that constitute the work being accomplished must be visually clear.
Users with appropriate permissions can select and view different defined business processes.

metadata.raw_input: A graphical representation of a business process helps tell a story of who participates in a process, what types of information are exchanged between the participants, and how the work is accomplished.

title: Business Process Visualization

The graphical representation must clearly label all actors/roles involved in the process.
The diagram must depict the flow of information between actors, including the type of data exchanged.
The sequence of tasks, decision points, and process start/end points must be visually clear.
A user with appropriate permissions can access and view the process visualization.

title: Use of Non-Technical Language
statement: A key aspect of the effectiveness of CRDM is the use of nontechnical language that is familiar to users and subject matter experts.
acceptance_criteria: Usability testing with representative users demonstrates a comprehension rate of 95% or higher for key system terms and messages.
A glossary of system terms is created and approved by a panel of subject matter experts and user representatives.
System interface and documentation are reviewed and found to be free of technical jargon not common to the target user group.

metadata.raw_input: A key aspect of the effectiveness of CRDM is the use of nontechnical language that is familiar to users and subject matter experts.

title: Use of Non-Technical Language
statement: A key aspect of the effectiveness of CRDM is the use of nontechnical language that is familiar to users and subject matter experts.
regulation: ISO - 62366-1 (Application of usability engineering to medical devices)
acceptance_criteria: All user-facing text, including labels, instructions, and error messages, must be reviewed and approved by a panel of representative users (e.g., clinicians, patients) for clarity and avoidance of technical jargon.
Usability testing with target users must demonstrate a task completion success rate of >= 95% for core system functions, with user errors related to language ambiguity being less than 2%.
A formal review of all UI text against a pre-defined glossary of approved, non-technical terms must be completed and passed.

title: User-Friendly Terminology
statement: A key aspect of the effectiveness of the system is the use of non-technical language that is familiar to users and subject matter experts.
acceptance_criteria: All user-facing text (labels, messages, help content) is written in plain language, avoiding technical jargon.
Usability testing with a panel of representative users (clinicians, SMEs) confirms that system terminology is clear and unambiguous.
A glossary of system-specific terms is maintained and is consistent with industry-standard vocabulary.
User feedback during testing indicates a high level of comprehension, with less than 5% of participants reporting confusion due to terminology.

title: Requirement Prioritization
statement: A mechanism must be established to classify requirements as either essential (must-have) or non-essential (nice-to-have) to guide development, validation, and release planning.
acceptance_criteria: A field or tag is available for each requirement to mark its essentiality (e.g., 'Essential', 'Nice-to-have').
The project's requirements documentation or backlog can be filtered and sorted based on this classification.
The criteria for what constitutes an 'Essential' requirement are clearly defined and documented, referencing factors like patient safety, regulatory compliance, and core clinical workflow.

metadata.raw_input: • Are there any requirements that are essential to address while others would be nice to have but not essential?

title: Process for Ongoing Requirement Updates
statement: A process must be established for the insurance technology community to contribute to ongoing updates, ensuring the requirements document remains a valuable and current 'living resource' to support national health insurance systems and Universal Health Coverage goals.
acceptance_criteria: A formal process for submitting, reviewing, and incorporating updates to the requirements is documented and approved.
A designated group or role is assigned responsibility for managing the update process.
A communication channel is established for the insurance technology community to provide contributions and feedback.
The requirements document is scheduled for periodic review (e.g., annually) to ensure its continued value.

metadata.raw_input: In addition, this document suggests a way forward for the insurance technology community to contribute to ongoing updates to ensure these requirements continue to have value as a living resource. title: Insurance Information System Integrity and Performance
statement: Strong health insurance information systems can ensure timely reimbursements, decrease transaction costs, find system efficiencies, prevent fraud, and ensure equitable coverage and treatment.
regulation: HIPAA - Security Rule (45 CFR Part 164 Subpart C)
acceptance_criteria: The system must process 95% of clean claims within the contractually obligated timeframe (e.g., 30 days).
The system shall provide analytics dashboards to identify and report on transaction costs and workflow efficiencies.
The system must include a fraud detection module that flags suspicious claims based on configurable rules and patterns.
Audit logs must demonstrate that coverage and reimbursement rules are applied consistently, without bias related to patient demographics.
All PHI and financial data must be encrypted at rest and in transit.

title: HL7 FHIR Compliance for Data Exchange
statement: The digital health system shall utilize HL7 FHIR and other relevant global standards to ensure standardized data exchange and alignment of business processes with other connected systems.
acceptance_criteria: The system can successfully transmit a patient data bundle to an external system using a valid HL7 FHIR message format.
The system can successfully receive and correctly parse a patient data bundle from an external system via an HL7 FHIR message.
Data integrity is maintained during transmission and reception, verified by checksums or data comparison.
The system's FHIR implementation passes validation against a standard FHIR validator tool for all supported resource types.

title: Core Capabilities for National-Scale Health Insurance Information System
statement: The health insurance information system must be designed to support national-scale schemes by ensuring timely reimbursements, decreasing transaction costs, identifying system efficiencies, preventing fraud, and ensuring equitable coverage and treatment for all members.
regulation: GDPR - Article 5 (Principles relating to processing of personal data)
HIPAA - 45 CFR Part 164 Subpart C (Security Rule)
HIPAA - 45 CFR Part 164 Subpart E (Privacy Rule)
acceptance_criteria: The system must process 95% of standard electronic claims for reimbursement within 15 business days.
The system must include a fraud detection module that automatically flags claims matching predefined suspicious patterns with a false positive rate below 5%.
The system must provide reporting capabilities to analyze transaction costs, with the goal of demonstrating a measurable decrease year-over-year.
The system must be able to generate on-demand reports to audit coverage and treatment patterns across various demographic segments to ensure equity.
Performance benchmarks must demonstrate the system's capacity to handle a load equivalent to the national user base without degradation in transaction processing times.
The system must pass annual security penetration tests with no critical or high-severity vulnerabilities identified.

metadata.raw_input: As a result, health insurance or health purchaser1 information systems are becoming more important as schemes are implemented at national scale. Strong health insurance information systems can ensure timely reimbursements, decrease transaction costs, find system efficiencies, prevent fraud, and ensure equitable coverage and treatment.

title: Scalable Information System for National Health Schemes
statement: The information system must be effective and scalable to support the expansion of access to health services for citizens under national health insurance schemes.
acceptance_criteria: The system shall support a minimum of 1,000,000 concurrent users with an average response time of less than 2 seconds for all critical transactions (e.g., eligibility check, claim submission).
The system shall demonstrate the ability to scale horizontally to accommodate a 50% growth in user base year-over-year without service degradation.
Under peak load testing, system resource utilization (CPU, Memory) shall not exceed 80% of provisioned capacity, ensuring stability.
The system must successfully process a batch of 10 million insurance claims within a 24-hour period.

metadata.raw_input: Conclusion Globally, countries are expanding access to health services to more of their citizens through the development of national health insurance schemes; the success of these efforts is highly dependent upon effective and scalable information systems.

title: Resource Usability and Maintenance

title: Software Evaluation Trade-offs
statement: The software selection and validation process must acknowledge that different software packages will exhibit varying levels of strength across the full set of requirements. A risk-based approach shall be used to evaluate and accept trade-offs, ensuring that any identified weaknesses are documented, assessed for impact, and mitigated by other controls or system components.
acceptance_criteria: A documented trade-off analysis or risk assessment is produced for any selected software package.
The analysis report identifies the strengths and weaknesses of the chosen software against key requirements.
Mitigation strategies for identified weaknesses are documented and approved by relevant stakeholders.

title: HIS/EHR System Integration
statement: The solution must be capable of integrating with existing Hospital Information Systems (HIS), such as Electronic Health Record (EHR) systems. The requirement includes defining whether standard interfaces (e.g., HL7, FHIR) will be used or if custom interface design is required. The priority of specific integration points (e.g., ADT, lab results, clinical notes) must be established, differentiating between essential ('must-have') and desirable ('nice-to-have') capabilities.
regulation: FDA 21 CFR Part 820 (if classified as a medical device)
acceptance_criteria: The solution successfully establishes a connection with a test HIS environment using a specified interface standard (e.g., HL7 v2.x, FHIR).
Data transmitted between the solution and the HIS is encrypted using TLS 1.2 or higher.
The system can successfully query and retrieve patient demographic data from the HIS.
Error handling mechanisms are documented and tested to manage failed integration attempts or data mismatches.
A clear distinction between essential and non-essential integration features is documented and approved by stakeholders.

metadata.raw_input: • Will the solution integrate with existing hospital information systems, or will it need to have interface design built into it? • Are there any requirements that are essential to address while others would be nice to have but not essential?

title: HIS Integration Capability
statement: The solution must be capable of integrating with existing hospital information systems (HIS) for data exchange. If direct integration is not feasible, an interface must be designed and built to facilitate this.
acceptance_criteria: The solution successfully establishes a connection with the target HIS using standard protocols (e.g., HL7, FHIR API).
Data can be successfully queried and retrieved from the HIS in real-time or near-real-time without data loss or corruption.
Data can be successfully transmitted to the HIS, correctly populating the designated fields.
All data transmissions between the solution and the HIS are encrypted in transit.
The integration's error rate for data transactions is less than 0.1% during performance testing.

title: HIS Integration and Interoperability
statement: The solution must be capable of integrating with existing hospital information systems (HIS) for seamless data exchange. If direct integration is not feasible, an interface must be designed and built to facilitate this data exchange.
acceptance_criteria: The solution successfully establishes a connection with the target HIS using standard protocols (e.g., HL7, FHIR API).

The integration must handle connection errors and data synchronization issues gracefully without data loss or corruption.

title: Hospital Information System (HIS) Integration

title: HIS Integration and Prioritization
statement: The solution must be evaluated for its capability to integrate with existing Hospital Information Systems (HIS), such as EHR, LIS, or PACS. A determination must be made whether standard interfaces (e.g., HL7, FHIR) can be used or if custom interface development is required. Additionally, all integration-related requirements must be categorized as either 'essential' (must-have) or 'non-essential' (nice-to-have).
regulation: HIPAA Privacy Rule (45 CFR Part 164 Subpart E)
HIPAA Security Rule (45 CFR Part 164 Subpart C)
acceptance_criteria: A technical assessment is completed, documenting the integration capabilities of the solution and the hospital's existing systems.
A list of required data exchange points (e.g., ADT messages, lab orders, results) is defined.
Each data exchange point is classified as 'essential' or 'non-essential' based on clinical and operational impact.
The required communication protocols (e.g., HL7 v2.x, FHIR R4) for essential integrations are identified and confirmed to be supported.
All data transmission channels for integration are confirmed to use industry-standard encryption (e.g., TLS 1.2+).

A set of specific, testable requirements derived from these rules is created and entered into the requirements management system.
The derived requirements are clearly categorized for provider-side and payer-side implementation.
The analysis and derived requirements are formally reviewed and approved by the compliance and legal departments.

title: Feasibility of Common Functional Requirements for National Health Systems
statement: The system architecture and design must address the challenge of defining common functional requirements that are reusable across different national health insurance systems, given the historical lack of system reuse between countries.
acceptance_criteria: A formal feasibility study is conducted and documented, analyzing the functional requirements of at least three different national health insurance systems.
A core set of common, reusable functional requirements is identified and formally approved by project stakeholders.
A gap analysis is produced, detailing the functional differences between national systems and the proposed common requirements.

title: Beneficiary Credential and Eligibility Verification
statement: The system must allow an Insurer to review a beneficiary's identification information (e.g., name, address, biometrics) and supporting documents to verify their validity and ensure all required data fields are complete. The system must also correctly identify and present all benefit plans for which the beneficiary qualifies.
regulation: HIPAA (45 CFR Part 164, Subpart E - Privacy Rule)
HIPAA (45 CFR Part 164, Subpart C - Security Rule)
acceptance_criteria: An authorized Insurer user can access the beneficiary's submitted identification information and documents.
The system must flag any incomplete or missing required fields in the beneficiary's data.
The system must provide a mechanism for the Insurer to mark the beneficiary's credentials as 'verified' or 'rejected'.
Upon successful verification, the system must display a complete list of all benefit plans the beneficiary is eligible for.
All access to and actions performed on the beneficiary's data must be logged in an audit trail.

title: Beneficiary Credential and Eligibility Verification
statement: The system must allow an Insurer to review a beneficiary's identification information (e.g., name, address, qualifying biometrics) and supporting documents to ensure validity and completeness. In the event a beneficiary qualifies for multiple benefits plans, the system must present all qualifying plans for appropriate processing.
regulation: HIPAA (45 CFR Part 164 - Security and Privacy)
acceptance_criteria: 1. An authorized Insurer user can access and view a beneficiary's submitted identification information and documents.
2. The system provides a clear interface for the Insurer to confirm that all required fields are complete and the documents are valid.
3. If a beneficiary is eligible for more than one benefits plan based on the validated data, the system displays all applicable plans to the Insurer.
4. The system logs the review and validation action, including the timestamp and the ID of the Insurer who performed the action, for audit trail purposes.

title: Clinician Access to Patient Lab Results
statement: The system must allow an authenticated and authorized clinician to securely access and view a patient's complete history of lab results. The view must include the test name, result value, reference range, collection date, and ordering physician.
regulation: HIPAA - 45 CFR § 164.502(a) Uses and Disclosures of PHI
acceptance_criteria: Given a logged-in clinician with appropriate permissions, when they select a patient, they can navigate to the lab results section.
The system displays a list of all historical lab results for the selected patient, sorted by collection date (newest first).
Each lab result entry correctly displays the test name, result value, reference range, and collection date.
A user without the 'clinician' role or without an established relationship with the patient cannot access the lab results and is shown an appropriate access denied message.
All access events to patient lab results are logged in the system audit trail, including user ID, patient ID, timestamp, and activity type.

title: System Process Activity Auditing
statement: The system must automatically record and maintain a secure audit log of all process activities involving access to, creation of, or modification of electronic protected health information (ePHI).
acceptance_criteria: When any actor accesses, creates, or modifies PHI, a corresponding entry is created in the audit log.

Each audit log entry must contain, at a minimum: user identification, date and time of the action, type of action (e.g., view, modify, delete), and the specific data object accessed (e.g., patient ID).
The audit logs must be immutable and protected against unauthorized access, modification, or deletion.
An authorized admin must be able to review and export the audit logs for a specified date range or user.

title: Scalable Information System for National Health Insurance
statement: The system must be an effective and scalable information platform to support the development and operation of national health insurance schemes. The system's design should be based on a set of common, reusable functional requirements to promote interoperability and successful adoption across different countries or regions.
acceptance_criteria: The system architecture must be documented and demonstrate the ability to scale to support a national-level user base.
A core set of common functional modules for health insurance (e.g., enrollment, claims processing, provider management) must be identified and implemented.
Performance benchmarks for scalability (e.g., transactions per second, concurrent users) must be defined and met during load testing.

metadata.raw_input: Conclusion Globally, countries are expanding access to health services to more of their citizens through the development of national health insurance schemes; the success of these efforts is highly dependent upon effective and scalable information systems. At the outset, experts questioned if common functional requirements were possible since to date there has been little reuse of national health insurance systems from country to country.

title: Support for Diverse Health Coverage Schemes
statement: The system must be architected to support a variety of country-specific health coverage schemes, accommodating differences in their design, coverage levels, and maturity. This includes the ability to configure and adapt to different functional, data, and regulatory requirements associated with each scheme.
acceptance_criteria: System can be configured to support at least two distinct national health coverage models (e.g., a US-based private insurance model and a UK-based NHS model).
Configuration for a new health scheme can be performed by an administrator through a dedicated interface without requiring new code deployment.
Rules for patient eligibility, service coverage, and billing logic must be adjustable based on the selected country scheme.

title: Jurisdictional and Organizational Configurability
statement: The system must be configurable to accommodate specific regulatory and operational requirements defined by different countries or organizations. This includes the ability to enable, disable, or modify features, rules, and workflows based on the deployment's specific jurisdiction or institutional policies.
acceptance_criteria: An administrator can configure system behavior based on a selected country (e.g., USA, Germany).
An administrator can define and apply a new set of rules specific to an organization's policy.
System features subject to regulation (e.g., data retention periods, consent requirements) can be modified through the administration interface without requiring a new code deployment.
The system correctly enforces the configured rules for the specified jurisdiction or organization during operation.

title: Adaptability to Regional Health Coverage Variations
statement: The system must be designed to accommodate and adapt to variations in country-specific health coverage schemes, including differences in design, coverage levels, and maturity. This requires a flexible architecture that allows for the configuration of different requirement sets based on the operational jurisdiction.
acceptance_criteria: GIVEN the system is being configured for Country A with a specific health coverage scheme, WHEN an administrator sets the jurisdiction to Country A, THEN the system's functional behavior (e.g., billing, data sharing rules) must align with the pre-defined requirements for Country A.

GIVEN the system is configured for Country B with a different health coverage scheme, WHEN a user performs an action (e.g., submitting a claim), THEN the system must enforce the rules and workflows specific to Country B's scheme.
The system must provide a mechanism for administrators to define and manage requirement sets for different jurisdictions without requiring a new code deployment.

title: Improve Data Quality
statement: The system must implement mechanisms to ensure and improve the quality, accuracy, and integrity of all stored and processed data, mitigating common data quality issues such as duplicates, inaccuracies, and incompleteness.
acceptance_criteria: Data entry fields for critical data (e.g., date of birth, medication dosage, lab values) must have built-in validation rules, including format, range, and type checks.
The system must include a mechanism to detect and flag potential duplicate patient records with a matching accuracy of at least 95%.

An administrative dashboard must be available to display data quality metrics, including completeness, consistency, and validity for key data types, with a target of >99% accuracy for critical fields.
An audit trail must log all changes to critical data, including the user, timestamp, and previous/new values.
Data imported from external sources must be processed through a validation layer to check for conformity to internal data standards before being integrated.

title: Enhance Data Integrity and Quality
statement: The system must implement mechanisms to improve and maintain a high level of data quality, addressing common issues such as inaccuracies, incompleteness, and inconsistencies in patient and clinical data to ensure patient safety and regulatory compliance.
acceptance_criteria: Input validation must be implemented on all critical data entry fields (e.g., date of birth, medication dosage, national patient identifiers) to prevent common format errors.

The system shall provide a data quality dashboard for administrators, reporting on completeness and consistency for key data types (e.g., percentage of patient records with a valid primary diagnosis).
A mechanism for detecting and merging duplicate patient records must be available to authorized administrators.
Automated checks must be in place to flag logically inconsistent data, such as a male patient with a pregnancy diagnosis.
Data entry error rates, as measured by periodic audits, must demonstrate a measurable reduction post-implementation.

title: Data Quality and Integrity Analysis
statement: The system must support the analysis of business processes to improve data quality. This includes capabilities to identify data entry points (both direct collection and from external systems), track how data is processed and analyzed, and monitor how data is shared with users and other systems to ensure its integrity and accuracy.
acceptance_criteria: The system must provide tools or logs to trace a data element from its point of entry (manual or system import) to its final presentation or export.
The system must have configurable validation rules at data entry points to minimize common data entry errors (e.g., format validation, range checks, required fields).
The system must be able to generate reports on data lineage and processing history for a selected data set or patient record.
An analysis of critical business processes (e.g., patient registration, lab result entry) must demonstrate the ability to identify data sources, transformations, and sharing points.

title: Support for National Health Insurance and Universal Health Coverage
statement: The system must support the operationalization of health financing transactions for paying for and delivering health services, as part of the national progress toward Universal Health Coverage for its citizens.
acceptance_criteria: The system provides functionalities to manage health financing transactions.
The system supports workflows for processing payments for health services (e.g., claims processing).
The system supports workflows related to the delivery of health services (e.g., patient eligibility verification).
System features and architecture are demonstrably aligned with the country's official Universal Health Coverage strategy documents.

title: Use of Non-Technical Language
statement: The system must use non-technical language that is familiar to users and subject matter experts to ensure effectiveness and ease of use across all interfaces and documentation.
acceptance_criteria: Usability testing with representative users demonstrates a task completion success rate of 95% or higher for key workflows.
A panel of subject matter experts must review and approve all user-facing terminology and labels for clarity and familiarity.
All user-facing text must achieve a Flesch-Kincaid grade level score of 8 or lower.
No technical jargon or system-specific acronyms are present in the user interface without a clear, accessible definition or tooltip.

title: Cross-Country Functional Requirement Harmonization
statement: The system shall be designed based on a core set of harmonized functional requirements common to all target countries, as identified through the application of the CRDM (Country Requirements Definition Matrix).
acceptance_criteria: A Country Requirements Definition Matrix (CRDM) that maps features to country-specific regulations and functional needs is created and approved.
A core set of functional requirements, common to all target countries, is formally defined, documented, and version-controlled.
System architecture and design specifications explicitly reference the core functional requirements.
A gap analysis is documented for each target country, identifying and addressing any unique local requirements not covered by the core set.

title: Cross-Domain System Applicability
statement: The system shall be designed with a flexible and modular architecture, inspired by the CRDM's adaptability, to support its use and extension into various domains beyond health insurance, including but not limited to logistics management and maternal health information systems.
acceptance_criteria: Architectural design review confirms a modular design that separates core platform services from domain-specific applications.
A proof-of-concept demonstrates the system's adaptation for a secondary domain (e.g., maternal health) with a defined, minimal level of effort.
API and extension documentation is available and reviewed for clarity and completeness.

title: Scheme Process Customization
statement: The system shall outline the differences between available process options, allowing authorized users to understand the breadth of choices and select the processes most relevant to their country's scheme.
regulation: GDPR - Article 25 (Data protection by design and by default)
ISO 9001 - 8.3 Design and development of products and services
acceptance_criteria: Given an authorized administrator is logged into the system, when they navigate to the scheme configuration section, then a comprehensive list of available process options is displayed.
For each process option, a clear description highlighting its function and differences from other options must be presented.
The administrator must be able to select and save a configuration of processes for their specific scheme.
The system must provide a confirmation that the selected configuration has been successfully applied.
The chosen processes must be correctly reflected in the scheme's subsequent operations and workflows.

title: Clinical Inquiry Feature
statement: The system shall provide a secure feature for authorized care team members to ask essential questions related to patient care, treatment plans, or other clinical data.

title: Stakeholder Data Access for Business Process Management
statement: The system shall provide authorized stakeholders with the necessary reporting and data analysis tools to effectively identify, monitor, and resolve issues within specific business processes by providing access to relevant data.
regulation: HIPAA (45 CFR Part 164, Subpart E - Privacy Rule)
HIPAA (45 CFR Part 164, Subpart C - Security Rule)
acceptance_criteria: Given an authorized stakeholder (e.g., Business Analyst), when they navigate to the reporting module, they can select a specific business process (e.g., Patient Intake).
The system must display a dashboard with relevant KPIs and metrics for the selected business process.
The user must be able to filter the data by date range and other relevant parameters (e.g., location, department) to investigate specific issues.
The system must provide a feature to export the filtered data or report in a standard format (e.g., CSV, PDF).
All access to data containing PHI for reporting purposes must be recorded in the system's audit log, detailing the user, timestamp, and data accessed.

title: Data Quality and Integrity Analysis
statement: The system shall support the analysis of business processes to identify and improve data quality. This includes determining data entry points (direct collection or from other systems), how data are processed and analyzed, and how data are shared with users and other systems.
acceptance_criteria: The system must provide a mechanism (e.g., audit logs, data lineage reports) to trace data from its point of entry to its final use or destination.
It must be possible to generate reports that identify all data sources (e.g., manual entry, specific EMR interface, patient portal).
The system must log all processing and analysis steps applied to data, including the algorithms or rules used.
Reports must be available to show how and with whom data is shared (e.g., specific users, external systems via API).
A data quality dashboard must be available to administrators, highlighting potential issues like missing fields, invalid formats, or inconsistencies.

title: Task Set Definition

title: Use of Non-Technical Language
statement: The system shall use nontechnical language, terminology, and phrasing that is familiar to its intended users and subject matter experts to ensure clarity, reduce errors, and improve effectiveness.
acceptance_criteria: A glossary of all user-facing terms is created and approved by a panel of representative subject matter experts and end-users.
Usability testing with a representative group of end-users demonstrates that 95% of users can understand and correctly interpret system labels, instructions, and messages without external help.
During user acceptance testing, no critical or major issues related to confusing or technical language are identified.

title: Core Beneficiary Management
statement: While some schemes may not require beneficiary enrollment and another may require it, both systems will require some level of beneficiary management.
regulation: HIPAA - 45 CFR § 164.502 (Uses and disclosures of protected health information)
acceptance_criteria: An authorized user (e.g., admin) can access a central beneficiary management module.
The system provides functionality to create, view, and update beneficiary records, regardless of the enrollment requirements of their associated scheme.
Access to beneficiary management functions is restricted by user role, preventing unauthorized access or modification.
All actions performed on beneficiary records (e.g., creation, updates) are logged in an audit trail.

metadata.raw_input: While some schemes may not require beneficiary enrollment and another may require it, both systems will require some level of beneficiary management.

title: Beneficiary Management Capability
statement: While some schemes may not require beneficiary enrollment and another may require it, both systems will require some level of beneficiary management.
regulation: HIPAA (Privacy Rule: 45 CFR Part 164, Subpart E)
HIPAA (Security Rule: 45 CFR Part 164, Subpart C)
acceptance_criteria: An authorized user can create a beneficiary record in the system.
An authorized user can search for and view the details of an existing beneficiary.
An authorized user can update the information of an existing beneficiary.
An authorized user can change the status of a beneficiary (e.g., active, inactive, archived).
All actions related to beneficiary management are logged in an audit trail.

metadata.raw_input: While some schemes may not require beneficiary enrollment and another may require it, both systems will require some level of beneficiary management.
